LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

Islamic Republic of Afghanistan 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communications 
Subsector: Roads and highways 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth 
Subtheme: Fostering physical infrastructure development 
 
Category B 
An initial environmental examination was undertaken. The 
summary is attached as an appendix. 
 
The  Project  is  to  (i)  rehabilitate  the  Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf 
road  (140.3  kilometers  [km])  and  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road 
(98.9  km),  (ii)  install  cross-border  facilities  in  Spin  Boldak,  (iii) 
support campaigns to prevent HIV/AIDS and increase awareness 
of human trafficking; (iv) provide support for project management 
and  monitoring,  and  (v)  provide  project  management  support  to 
the Ministry of Public Works (MPW).  
 
Since rehabilitation of roads started after more than two decades 
of  conflict,  the  focus  of  the  road  rehabilitation  program  has  been 
the reconstruction and completion of the regional highways. Once 
the  current  or  planned  projects  are  completed  by  2008,  the 
existing  regional  highway  network  will  be  improved  to  a  two-lane 
bitumen-paved road standard, with certain four-lane sections near 
Kabul  and  Kandahar.  In  contrast,  more  than  90%  of  national 
highways  and  provincial  roads  are  either  earth  or  gravel,  and 
more  than  60%  are  in  poor  condition.  Many  are  impassable  at 
specific  locations  such  as  rivers  and  where  severe  erosion  or 
landslides  have  occurred.  Except  for  newly  constructed  bridges, 
most bridges and culverts along national highways and provincial 
roads  are  in  bad  condition.  Many  are  in  danger  of  collapse  from 
heavily loaded vehicles or of being washed away.  
 
The Government’s next priority is development of the north–south 
and east–west corridors, which connect the ring road horizontally 
and  perpendicularly  and  improves  access  for  people  living  in 
remote areas at the center of the country.  
 
During  the  first  phase  of  road  rehabilitation,  after  resuming  its 
operation  in  Afghanistan  in  2002,  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) gave priority attention to rehabilitation of regional highways, 
particularly  the  ring  road,  with  emphasis  on  trade  links  to 
neighboring  countries,  including  bridges,  disintegrated  pavement, 
drainage  erosion  protection,  and  routine  maintenance.  With 
rehabilitation  of  regional  highways  nearing  completion,  ADB  is 
placing   priority    on   connecting   the   ring   road   through    the

by  the  road  master  plan  prepared  with  ADB  assistance.  The

as Mazar-e-Sharif and Kabul, through which the ring road passes. 
 
Afghanistan has made significant progress since the ouster of the 
Taliban regime. The  Government has implemented a wide range 
of  structural  reforms  and  adhered  to  almost  all  quantitative 
indicators  and  structural  benchmarks  under  the  Staff-Monitored 
Program, led by the International Monetary Fund. Notwithstanding 
these achievements and sustained economic growth over the last 
2  years,  the  economic  and  fiscal  situation  continues  to  be 
extremely  fragile.  Security,  economic,  social,  and  administrative 
challenges are formidable. Afghanistan continues to need external 
development  finance  that  does  not  fiscally  burden  the  nascent 
administration. To achieve growth  targets over the medium term, 
the  Government  must  aim  for  broad-based  and  sustainable 
development and identify new drivers of growth. Investment in the 
road  sector  is  a  prerequisite  for  sustained  economic  growth,  and 
the grant will greatly help accelerate this transition.  
 
 
The  Project  will  help  the  Government  to  promote  economic  and 
social  development,  and  reduce  poverty  by  rehabilitating  the 
national highway network to connect the central remote regions of 
Afghanistan to the ring road.  
 
The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $140.9 million, 
including taxes and duties of $1.7 million.  
 
A  loan  of  $78.2  million  and  a  grant  of  $40.0  million  from  ADB’s 
Special  Fund  resources  will  be  provided.  The  proposed  loan  will 
have a term of 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with 
an annual interest rate of 1% per annum. The total amount of the 
interest  charge  during  the  grace  period  will  be  capitalized  and 
charged to the loan account. The grant will finance (i) resettlement 
costs,  (ii)  civil  works  for  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road,  (iii) 
campaigns  to  prevent  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking,  and  (iv) 
incremental project management support. The loan will finance (i) 
civil  works  for  the  Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf  road,  (ii)  cross-
border facilities, and (iii) project management and monitoring.  
 
The ADB loan and grant totaling $118.2 million will finance 84 % 
of  the  project  cost,  excluding  land  acquisition,  and  taxes  and 
duties  of  $2.7  million,  which  will  be  incurred  by  the  Government. 
The  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  will  provide  an  additional 
grant  of  $20  million  to  finance  civil  works  for  the  Bamian–
Yakawlang road.

The Project will lead to both direct and indirect poverty reduction 
impacts.  The  direct  poverty  impact  will  be  on  income  generation 
and  demand  for  unskilled  labor  and  wages  accruing  during 
construction of the project road. Other benefits will be lower travel 
time  and  travel  costs,  and  higher  agricultural  product  profit 
margins.  
 
Improved roads will lead to a shift from subsistence agriculture to 
market-based  production  enabling  farmers  to  grow  perishable 
commercial products like vegetables and fruits and transport them 
more quickly to markets. The farmers in the provinces will be able 
to  diversify  their  cropping  patterns;  cultivate  high-value  crops; 
grow larger marketable surpluses to improve their income earning 
capacities;  and  generate  more  agricultural  wage  employment, 
particularly benefiting the poor. 
 
Improved  road  conditions  will  lead  to  growth  of  affordable 
transport  facilities  and  thus  the  poor,  especially  women  and 
children  will  have  more  reliable,  affordable,  and  timely  access  to 
educational  and  medical  facilities.  Lower  transportation  costs  will

A. 
 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

1. 

Road Infrastructure 

 
2. 
Afghanistan  is  a  landlocked  country.  With  a  large  area  (about  652,000  square 
kilometers)  and  an  estimated  population  of  22.8  million  widely  spread  across  the  largely 
mountainous  terrain,  roads  are  the  principal  means  of  transport.  The  road  network  comprises 
about 3,300 kilometers (km) of regional highways, 4,900 km of national highways, 9,700 km of 
provincial roads, 17,000–23,000 km of rural roads, and about 3,000 km of urban roads including 
1,060  km  in  Kabul.  Regional  highways  (comprising  the  2,300  km  ring  road  that  connects 
Afghanistan’s  major  regional  centers  [Herat,  Kandahar,  Mazar-e-Sharif,  Maymaneh,  and 
Sheberghan]  with  Kabul,  and  the  roads  linking  to  neighboring  countries)  foster  regional  trade 
and economic linkages between Afghanistan and neighboring countries such as Iran, Pakistan, 
Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan.  National  highways  extend  regional  highways  to 
provincial  capitals  contributing  to  economic  growth  and  national  integration.  Provincial  roads 
improve  the  administrative,  trade,  and  economic  contacts  between  district  headquarters  and 
respective  provincial  capitals,  and  between  important  district  headquarters;  while  rural  roads 
bring remote areas into commercial contact with markets.  
 
Since  rehabilitation  of  roads  started  after  more  than  two  decades  of  conflict,  the  road 
3. 
rehabilitation  program  has  focused  on  reconstruction  and  completion  of  regional  highways. 
Once  the  current  or  planned  projects  are  completed  by  2008,  the  existing  regional  highway 
network  will  be  improved  to  a  two-lane  bitumen-paved  road  standard,  with  certain  four-lane 
sections  near  Kabul  and  Kandahar.  In  contrast,  more  than  90%  of  national  highways  and 
provincial  roads  are  either  earth  or  gravel,  and  over  60%  are  in  poor  condition.  Many  are

highways  and  provincial  roads  are  in  poor  condition.  Many  are  in  danger  of  collapse  from 
heavily loaded vehicles or of being washed away.  
 

2. 

Road Transport Service 

 
4. 
The number of vehicles has increased significantly over the past 2 years. According to 
statistics  provided  in  a  recent  International  Monetary  Fund  country  report  on  Afghanistan, 
transport of goods by road increased from 1.9 million tons in 2000, to 3.7 million tons in 2001 
and  5  million  tons  in  2002,  representing  an  almost  fourfold  increase.  The  number  of  taxicabs 
nearly  doubled  from  17,000  in  2000  to  33,500  in  2002.  More  than  147,000  vehicles  are 
estimated to be registered in Kabul. Most vehicles are owned and operated by the private sector 
as the Ministry of Transport-operated fleet has been severely depleted.  
 
5. 
The  Afghan  private  sector  has  historically  played  a  dominant  role  in  trucking  and  has 
maintained its presence, including individuals and firms that relocated in Pakistan during the war

years.  Long  distance  public  transport,  linking  major  cities  and  neighboring  countries,  which 
deteriorated due to road and vehicle conditions as well as suppressed demand for road travel, 
has  been  regaining  its  role.  However,  security  remains  a  key  impediment  for  its  full-scale 
restoration of operations.  
 
6. 
Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  mostly  provided  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans, but with little regulation. It is constrained by lack of 
transport capacity; congestion, pollution; lack of accessibility; inadequate route coverage; poor 
road condition; and lack of depots, stops, and terminals as well as designated road space. The 
urban  transport  system  needs  integrated  planning.  Vehicle  fleet  support  services  are  mostly 
privately  provided,  with  government  workshops  operating  poorly,  including  those  at  border 
points.  Forms  of  regional  transport  depend  on  the  state  of  the  roads  and  the  availability  of 
vehicles.  People  and  goods  move  together,  blurring  distinction  between  passenger  and 
commercial  freight  traffic.  Private  agencies  operate  provincial  and  district  routes.  Some  165 
registered  long-distance  private  bus  companies  are  estimated  to  be  operating—101  based  in 
Kabul, 64 in the provinces—with a total of 14,007 buses, mostly old minibuses and vans. 
 

3. 

Road Sector Management 

 
7. 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW)  is  responsible  for  development,  operation,  and 
maintenance of regional highways, national highways, and provincial roads in the country. It had 
a  large  engineering  organization  with  staff  stationed  in  every  major  provincial  capital  carrying 
out  work  through  force  account.  Over  the  course  of  the  conflict,  MPW  lost  most  of  its  trained 
staff.  The  current  staff  of  2,900  require  substantial  skill  enhancement  to  perform  their  duties. 
The  Ministry  of  Rehabilitation  and  Rural  Development  is  responsible  for  development  of  rural 
infrastructure,  including  rural  roads.  Municipalities  are  responsible  for  the  construction  and 
maintenance of urban roads. 
 
The Ministry of Transport regulates the private sector transport industry. With a current 
8. 
staffing level of 1,180, the ministry’s primary function now is coordinating agreements between 
private sector and international transporters, and establishing offices in neighboring countries to 
facilitate  international  trade.  The  ministry’s  private  sector  department  sets  technical  standards 
for  private  commercial  vehicles  and  inspects  them  for  compliance  during  the  licensing  and 
renewal process. It collects a fee of 5% per carriage contract from private trucks and 3% per trip 
from interprovincial private buses, based on authorized charge rates. These fees are collected 
at national or provincial borders or the outskirts of major cities.

10.

building  activities.  Afghanistan  is  receiving  extensive  assistance  from  the  international  aid 
community  to  reconstruct  and  develop  the  road  network.  For  regional  highways,  almost  $1.2 
billion  has  been  provided  or  committed  to  rehabilitate  3,100  km  of  roads.  These  rehabilitation

ADB’s Strategy 

 
12. 
ADB  places  its  first  priority  on  rehabilitating  the  road  system,  which  is  critical  for  a 
landlocked country. According to the Initial Country Strategy and Program (2002–2004),2 roads 
are needed to rebuild the economy  by establishing major economic linkages domestically and 
with  neighboring  countries.  The  strategic  direction  for  the  rehabilitation,  reconstruction,  and 
development of the road sector comprises (i) policy and institutional development; (ii) capacity 
building;  (iii)  private  sector  development;  (iv)  employment  generation;  (v)  community 
participation; (vi) decentralization of network management; (vii) sustainable sector financing and 
cost  recovery;  (viii)  protection  and  preservation  of  the  environment;  (ix)  avoidance  and 
mitigation  of  resettlement;  and  (x)  involvement  of  returnee  refugees,  ex-combatants,  women, 
and the nongovernment organization (NGO) community in road construction and maintenance.

2002, ADB gave priority attention to rehabilitating regional highways, particularly the ring road, 
with  emphasis  on  trade  links  to  neighboring  countries,  including  bridges,  disintegrated

16. 
Routine  road  maintenance  expenditures  are  projected  to  increase  steadily  as  road 
projects are completed: from $8 million in 2006 to $25 million in 2015. Periodic maintenance will 
not be required until 2010, when expenditures will increase significantly to about $45 million per 
year  from  2011  to  2015  when  the  regional  and  national  highway  projects  currently  under 
construction will require their first periodic maintenance.  
 
17. 
The  most  immediate  maintenance  requirement  is  for  special  maintenance  works  on 
national highways and provincial roads of which maintenance has long been delayed, beginning 
with  an  estimated  $26  million  in  2006  and  gradually  decreasing  to  $14  million  in  2015  as  the

maintenance ranges from $34 million to $47 million; this will increase to $87 million for 2011–
2015 because of the significant increase of periodic maintenance. 
 
The expected road revenue falls far short of the required road maintenance expenditure.

participation in regional cooperation initiatives.

Lessons Learned 

 
37. 
A number of lessons can be drawn from past ADB emergency assistance projects, best 
practices, as well as ADB’s initial lending and nonlending operations in Afghanistan since 2002: 
(i) continued emphasis has to be given to capacity building to improve planning, project design 
and  implementation,  administration,  and  financial  management;  (ii)  aid  coordination  through 
government-aid  consultative  groups  or  other  mechanisms  is  important  to  avoid  duplication  or 
delays; (iii) aid groups must work closely with a country’s finance ministry and central bank to 
develop  a  viable  and  working  payment  system,  without  which  maintaining  a  flow  of  funds  is 
difficult; (iv) capacity building in executing agencies is vital, and consulting services for project 
design and implementation should explicitly provide for the training of executing agency staff in 
the  operation  and  maintenance  of  rehabilitated  facilities;  (v)  the  number  of  procurement 
packages should be minimized, given the limited implementation capacity for project execution; 
(vi)  ADB’s  procurement  guidelines  should  be  applied  flexibly  to  allow  reduced  procurement 
periods for the urgent delivery of project components; and (vii) law and order situations resulting 
from conflict hamper the smooth implementation of projects, and detailed security plans must be 
in place to address possible security hazards in project locations. From experience with project 
implementation in Afghanistan, lessons include (i) procurement actions need to be taken far in 
advance  to  expedite  implementation,  and  (ii)  recruitment  of  consultants  should  be  expedited. 
These  lessons  of  experience  are  fully  incorporated  in  the  project  design,  and  in  particular, 
procurement actions will proceed in parallel with project processing to avoid any start-up delay 
of project implementation.

Social and Poverty Impacts 

 
A. 
 
In  Afghanistan,  nearly  53%  of  the  population  are  classified  as  poor22 and  live  on  less 
68. 
than $1 a day. The project road passes through the provinces of Balkh, Samangan, and Bamian 
and will benefit a total population of 1,735,800.23 Before the war, these provinces were known 
for their agriculture, livestock, handicrafts, and carpet industry. The existing road condition is the 
biggest constraint as people are unable to transport their products to market and currently crops 
are  grown  on  a  small  scale  only  for  household  consumption.  Poverty  in  these  provinces  is 
estimated  to  be  60%  with  the  majority  of  the  population  living  in  mud  houses  (80%–95%) 
without electricity, clean water, proper sanitation facilities, and garbage disposal system. As per 
the  data  available,  only  10%–11%  of  the  households  in  these  three  provinces  had  access  to 
clean water; only 10% in Balkh province had a garbage disposal system. The social assessment 
indicates  that  the  population  living  along  the  proposed  alignment  is  generally  poor  with  about 
48%  having  an  annual  income  of  less  than  $600  with  an  average  household  size  of  9.  The 
survey also indicates that 75% were engaged in subsistence agriculture and allied activities for 
their livelihood, while the rest had small businesses in the town areas.  
 
The  Project  will  lead  to  both  direct  and  indirect  poverty  reduction  impacts.  The  direct 
69. 
poverty  impact  will  be  on  income  generation  and  demand  for  unskilled  labor  and  wages 
accruing  during  construction  of  the  project  road.  Other  benefits  will  be  lower  travel  time  and 
travel  costs,  and  higher  agricultural  product  profit  margins.  Improved  roads  will  lead  to  a  shift 
from  subsistence  agriculture  to  market-based  production  enabling  farmers  to  grow  perishable 
commercial products like vegetables and fruits and to more quickly transport them to markets. 
Improved road conditions will lead to growth of affordable transport facilities and thus the poor, 
especially  women  and  children  will  have  more  reliable,  affordable,  and  timely  access  to 
educational and medical facilities. Lower transportation costs will also increase mobility among 
the poor to find employment opportunities in other areas. Increased access to local and national 
markets  will  lead  to  growth  of  local  trade  and  production  activities,  and  reduced  prices  of 
agricultural commodities and other products. Thus increased economic activity and easy access 
to  social  services  are  expected  to  significantly  increase  household  incomes  and  quality  of  life 
thereby reducing overall poverty incidence. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy 
is in Appendix 11.

The  economic  analysis  was  conducted  separately  for  the  two  district  roads  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The highway design 
and maintenance model (HDM-IV) was used to calculate vehicle operating costs and time costs 
with modification for conditions in Afghanistan. The major inputs include vehicle characteristics 
and related costs, and construction and maintenance costs. The major benefits are derived from 
savings of vehicle operating costs and travel time due to rehabilitation of the project road, which 
will provide a stimulus for economic growth in the project area.

duties  excluded.  A  standard  conversion  factor  of  0.95  was  applied  to  the  financial  costs  of 
nontraded inputs to calculate economic prices.

The  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  is  the  road  transport  regulator,  road  transport  service

provider, as well as policymaker. It regulates the private sector transport industry and manages 
the government-owned vehicle fleet. Before 1978, freight and long distance bus services were 
left  to  the  private  sector,  while  the  public  sector  played  a  role  in  the  Kabul  bus  service.  New 
legislation  in  1978  authorized  the  Government  to  provide  nationwide  freight  and  passenger 
services.  In  1990,  MOT  reportedly  controlled  1,600  trucks,  1,000  buses,  and  extensive 
workshops. During the conflict, however, almost all fleets were lost. MOT provincial checkpoints 
that  once  tracked  performance  and  location  of  its  fleets  and  all  other  traffic  now  only  monitor 
private vehicles. 
 
6. 
With  a  current  staffing  level  of  1,180,  MOT’s  primary  function  now  is  coordinating 
agreements  between  private  sector  and  international  transporters,  and  establishing  offices  in 
neighboring countries to facilitate international trade. MOT is structured to have 10 departments 
under  the  minister  and  two  deputy  ministers.  Over  70%  of  the  staff  is  in  the  private  sector 
department,  which  sets  technical  standards  for  private  commercial  vehicles,  inspects  them  for 
compliance during the licensing/renewal process, and collects a carriage fee from private trucks 
and  a  trip  fee  from  interprovincial  private  buses.  These  fees  are  collected  at  national  or 
provincial borders or the outskirts of major cities.  
 
7. 
The  Afghan  private  sector  has  historically  played  a  dominant  role  in  trucking  and 
maintained its presence, including individuals and firms that relocated in Pakistan during the war 
years.  Long  distance  public  transport,  linking  major  cities  and  neighboring  countries,  which 
deteriorated due to road and vehicle conditions as well as suppressed demand for road travel, 
has been regaining its role. However, security remains a major impediment for full restoration of 
operations.  
 
8. 
Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  mostly  provided  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans, but with little regulation. It is constrained by lack of 
transport capacity; congestion; pollution; lack of accessibility; inadequate route coverage; poor 
road condition; and lack of depots, stops, and terminals as well as designated road space. The 
urban  transport  system  needs  integrated  planning.  Vehicle  fleet  support  services  are  mostly 
privately  provided,  with  government  workshops  operating  poorly,  including  those  at  border 
points.  Forms  of  regional  transport  depend  on  the  state  of  the  roads  and  the  availability  of 
vehicles.  People  and  goods  move  together,  blurring  distinction  between  passenger  and 
commercial  freight  traffic.  Private  agencies  operate  provincial  and  district  routes.  Some  165 
registered  long-distance  private  bus  companies  are  estimated  to  be  operating—101  based  in 
Kabul, 64 in the provinces—with a total of 14,007 buses, mostly old minibuses and vans. 
 
9. 
The taxi system in Afghanistan is widespread and well organized. According to MOT, 24 
taxi  unions  registered  in  Kabul  and  27  in  the  provinces  have  a  total  of  29,131  vehicles. 
According to the Transport Sector Review, the real number of taxis in Kabul is perhaps 30,000. 
Taxis  seem  to  operate  freely,  with  little  adherence  to  zonal  or  any  other  rules.  In  addition, 
intermediate size vehicles of all sizes and shapes transport passengers and goods.

11. 
Over the course of the conflict, the Government ministries lost a majority of their trained 
staff. In provinces where staff and equipment were retained, they were often under the influence 
of provincial governments and not fully under the control of ministry headquarters in Kabul. This 
situation is gradually being realigned as the central Government successfully extends its control 
outside  Kabul  to  the  provinces.  The  current  staffing  level  of  MPW  is  about  2,900:  900  are 
employed on a permanent basis, 1,900 are paid daily wages, and 140 are military officers. Most 
of the current staff require substantial skill enhancement to perform their duties. 
 
12. 
To  fill  the  capacity  gap,  most  of  the  externally  funded  projects  are  being  implemented 
with  assistance  of  international  consultants  in  project  management.  Civil  works  are  packaged 
into  large  contracts  and  bid  out  through  competitive  procedures  to  private  sector  contractors. 
Consultants  engaged  by  MPW  supervise  the  works  of  contractors.  MPW  is  being  transformed 
into  a  lean  and  thin  organization  with  its  primary  task  being  nationwide  policy  formation, 
planning  of  the  countrywide  road  network,  setting  of  standards  (including  technical,  safety, 
social, and environmental safeguards), regulation and enforcement functions, and management 
of roads under its jurisdiction.

Introduction 

A. 
 
1. 
The proposed project road from Mazar-e-Sharif to Dara-I-Suf and Yakawlang to Bamian 
constitutes the north–south link connecting the central region of Afghanistan. The project road 
runs  through  the  remotest  and  least  developed  areas  of  the  country.  Rehabilitating  and 
improving the north–south link will contribute to promoting increased connectivity and linkages 
for  isolated  communities,  create  employment  opportunities  for  unskilled  laborers  involved  in 
road  construction  and  maintenance  (with  possible  targeting  of  internally  and/or  internationally 
displaced  persons  and  ex-combatants),  promote  increased  access  to  basic  social  services 
(education and health), and support income-generating opportunities for poor households. Other 
than  positive  impacts  on  poverty  reduction,  improved  transport  network  connectivity  (and  the 
related  increased  road  traffic  and  mobility)  will  encourage  the  introduction  of  sex  workers  and 
migrant labors, leading to a potential increase in the spread of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking 
risks in the project area. Women’s greater exposure to HIV/AIDS, sexually transmitted infections 
(STIs),  and,  increasingly,  human  trafficking  is  acknowledged  and  forms  the  rationale  for  the 
proposed initiatives under this component. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
Afghanistan is, on the surface, a conservative Islamic country, making the issues of sex, 
gender  relations,  and  HIV/AIDS  sensitive  issues  to  discuss.  HIV/AIDS  prevalence  as  reported 
by the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH) is 51 HIV cases and 4 deaths (as of 2006). Diagnostic 
capacity varies and the real number of cases may be far higher as screening has been limited to 
blood  donors.  Little  is  known  about  the  factors  that  influence  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS  in 
Afghanistan.  However,  many  existing  vulnerability  factors  could  fuel  the  epidemic,  and 
contribute to women’s greater vulnerability to the risks and impacts of HIV/AIDS. These include 
the following:

Human  trafficking  is  the  forced  removal  and  migration  of  people  against  their  will. 
According to the International Organisation for Migration, Afghanistan is prone to both internal 
and  international  trafficking.  Human  trafficking  victims  are  often  women  and  children,  usually 
destined  for  Middle  Eastern  countries.  Numerous  types  of  activities  are  related  to  human

4.  

Innovation  

 
There are no innovations in the design of the project in terms of poverty reduction interventions, 
being primarily a road construction project. However, to the extent possible, local labor will be 
used to generate local employment. 
 
Improved roads will also lead to shift from subsistence agriculture to market-based production 
enabling  farmers  to  grow  perishable  commercial  products  like  vegetables  and  fruits  allowing 
them to transport these goods at much shorter time. The farmers in the provinces would also be 
able  to  diversify  their  cropping  patterns,  cultivate  high-value  crops,  grow  larger  marketable 
surpluses  to  improve  their  income-earning  capacities  as  well  as  generate  more  agricultural 
wage employment, particularly benefiting the poor. 
 
Improved road conditions will lead to growth of affordable transport facilities and thus the poor, 
especially  women  and  children,  will  have  more  reliable,  affordable,  and  timely  access  to 
educational and medical facilities. Lower transportation costs will also increase mobility among 
the poor to find employment opportunities in other areas. Increased access to local and national 
markets will lead to growth of local trade, increased production activities, and reduced prices of 
agricultural commodities and other products.  
 

5.  

Sustainability 

 
Routine road maintenance expenditures are projected to increase steadily as road projects are 
completed,  from  $8  million  in  2006  to  $25  million  in  2015.  Periodic  maintenance  will  not  be 
required until 2010, when the expenditure will increase significantly to about $45 million per year 
from  2011  to  2015  because  the  regional  and  national  highway  projects  currently  under 
construction will reach the stage requiring the first periodic maintenance.

The  most  immediate  maintenance  requirement  is  for  special  maintenance  works  on  national 
highways and provincial roads of which maintenance has long been delayed, beginning with an 
estimated $26 million in 2006 and gradually decreasing to $14 million in 2015 as the backlog of 
work is eliminated. Over the period of 2006–2015, the need for special works will decrease while 
the  need  for  routine  and  periodic  maintenance  will  increase,  approximately  balancing  each 
other.  For  the  years  2006–2010,  the  average  maintenance  annual  maintenance  requirement 
including  routine,  periodic,  and  backlog  maintenance  ranges  from  $34  million  to  $47  million, 
while the same will increase to $87 million for the years of 2011–2015 because of the significant 
increase of periodic maintenance. 
 
The  expected  road  revenue,  however,  falls  far  short  of  the  required  road  maintenance 
expenditure.  The  main  source  of  road  revenue,  road  tolls  which  the  Government  will  reinstate 
for  rehabilitated  regional  highways,  is  expected  to  generate  $13  million–$23  million  for  the 
period of 2006–2015 on the basis of the toll rate of $0.005 per passenger car equivalent per km. 
Even  considering  vehicle  registration  fees  currently  collected  and  expected  to  generate  $3 
million–$6 million per year for the period of 2006–2015, the expected road revenue will be able 
to finance around 30%50% of road maintenance requirement.  
 
To  relieve  the  shortfall  of  road  revenue,  The  Government  will  evaluate  other  sustainable 
methods for revenue generation such as setting up a dedicated road maintenance fund based 
on  fuel  levies,  vehicles  licensing,  and  other  road-user  related  taxes;  and  will  complete  this 
evaluation by December 2007. At present, fuel prices in Afghanistan rank among the lowest in 
the  region  (about  $0.5 per  liter)  with  no  tax  levied  except  customs  duty  of  9%,  while  taxes  on 
fuel  in  other  countries  range  from  13%  to  70%.  Based  on  fuel  usage  and  estimated  vehicle 
population, the total amount of fuel used for road transport vehicles is estimated as 582 million 
liters per year, which can translate into $291 million in expenditure for fuel consumed by road 
users. If a 10%–15% fuel tax is introduced, it will generate $29 million–$48 million of additional 
road  revenue,  which  will  be  sufficient  to  cover  the  shortfall  of  current  road  revenue.  The 
development partners’ local consultative group, consisting of major financiers such as the World 
Bank,  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID),  and  Japan  Bank  for 
International Cooperation, considers introduction of fuel tax as one of its key agenda for policy 
dialogue and will continue its dialogue with the Government to secure stable financing sources 
for sustainable road maintenance.

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                        Poverty Classification: General intervention 
 
In Afghanistan, nearly 53% of the population are classified as poor1 and live on less than $1 a day. The project road 
passes  through  the  provinces  of  Balkh,  Samangan,  and  Bamian  and  will  benefit  a  total  population  of  1,735,800.2. 
Before  the  war,  these  provinces  were  known  for  their  agriculture,  livestock,  handicrafts,  and  carpets  industry.  The 
existing  road  condition  is  the  biggest  constraint  as  people  are  unable  to  transport  their  products  to  markets  and 
currently crops are grown  only  on a small scale,  which is enough for household consumption. Irrigation facilities are 
limited and few farmers still cultivate poppies to increase their income. Poverty in these provinces is estimated at 60%, 
with  most  of  the  population  living  in  mud  houses  (80–95%)  and  the  majority  of  households  living  without  electricity, 
clean  water,  proper  sanitation  facilities,  and  garbage  disposal.  As  per  the  data  available,  only  10%–11%  of  the 
households in these three provinces have access to clean water; only 10% in Balkh province have a garbage disposal 
system. The social assessment indicates that the population living along the proposed alignment is generally poor with 
about 48% having an annual income of less than $600 with an average household size of 9. The survey also indicates 
that  75%  are  engaged  in  subsistence  agriculture  and  allied  activities  for  their  livelihood,  while  the  rest  have  small 
businesses in the town areas.  
 
Afghanistan  ranks  4th  highest  for  under-5  mortality  rate  at  257  deaths/1,000;  the  infant  mortality  rate  is  at  a  high 
165/1,000.  Among  the  three  provinces  Balkh  has  four  hospitals,  Samangan  has  only  one  provincial  hospital,  and 
Bamian  has  only  one  district  hospital  with  a  limited  number  of  beds  to  cater  to  the  entire  population.  The  survey 
reveals that the local population in these provinces has to use private transport facilities to reach the hospitals, which 
is expensive due to poor road conditions and limited availability. Due to poor road conditions, some emergency cases 
could not reach the hospitals on time. Apart from difficulty accessing district and provincial hospitals, people travelled 
1–2 hours on foot to reach the nearest health center. Malnutrition among children is very common in the project area, 
while  adults  and  children  also  suffer  from  diseases  like  malaria,  diarrhoea,  and  bronchitis  due  to  the  unclean 
environment resulting from lack of clean water and air pollution. Lack of adequate and accessible educational facilities 
is another major problem in the project area. Although, the provinces have primary and secondary schools, only the 
population living near the towns send their children to school, while children living in smaller settlements are deprived 
of  schooling  due  to  poor  road  conditions  and  lack  of  transport  facilities.  Some  schools  lack  proper  buildings  and 
teaching equipment. Poor road conditions and accessibility also constrain teachers and health personnel from working 
in this region.
